children.value: Light is a powerful tool for exploring structures, but its wavelength fundamentally limits the resolution achievable. At the end of the 16th century, the microscope was invented to resolve and observe small structures, initially mainly biological samples such as seeds, plants, the eye of a fly and the structure of cork. Hooke, one of the first to use a microscope described the pores inside the cork as ‘cells’, the origin of the current use of the word in biology today.
In the classical limit, the smallest detail resolvable by conventional microscopy is approximately half the wavelength (2

children.html: λ\lambdaλ

children.value: ) of the light used. For visible light, this resolution limit is around 200-250 nanometers (nm), which is sufficient for resolving cells and large organelles, but far too large for atomic or molecular structures.
To resolve smaller structures like single crystals and individual atoms, which have characteristic spacings on the scale of

children.html: ≈0.1\approx 0.1≈0.1
1 nm1 \text{ nm}1 nm
10 Angstroms10 \text{ Angstroms}10 Angstroms

children.value: ), researchers must use “light” with a much shorter wavelength. For this, X-rays are commonly used as these have wavelengths comparable to the interatomic spacing in crystals. This allows for the determination of the atomic structure of crystals down to resolutions of

children.html: 0.1 nm0.1 \text{ nm}0.1 nm

children.value: or better, effectively resolving the positions of the constituent atoms.

To resolve structures smaller than the size of an atom’s position, one must move beyond using light (photons) and instead employ beams of high-energy fundamental particles, such as electrons or other particles. The key principle remains the same as with light: to resolve a feature, the probe’s de Broglie wavelength (

children.html: λ\lambdaλ

children.value: ) must be comparable to or smaller than the feature’s size. High-energy electrons can have de Broglie wavelengths of less than

children.html: 0.004 nm0.004 \text{ nm}0.004 nm

children.value: , significantly shorter than the atomic spacing of

children.html: ≈0.1 nm\approx 0.1 \text{ nm}≈0.1 nm

children.value: . This extremely small wavelength allows modern electron microscopes to not only resolve the regular positions of atoms in a crystal lattice but also to image individual atoms and distinguish different elements within a material, achieving resolutions approaching

children.html: 0.05 nm0.05 \text{ nm}0.05 nm

children.value: In SI units (i.e. the international system of units
) the de Broglie wavelength is defined as:

children.html: λ=hp\lambda = \frac{h}{p} \\λ=ph​
λ\lambdaλ

h=6.626×10−34m2h = 6.626 \times 10^{-34} m^2h=6.626×10−34m2
=6.626×10−34Js= 6.626 \times 10^{-34} J s =6.626×10−34Js

children.value: Nuclear and Particle physics requires going to even smaller scales: Electrons and protons are most often used in order to test the structure of matter. Even when accelerated to modest velocities, they can probe features much smaller than atoms.
Example: Wavelength of a proton travelling with

children.html: λ=hp=hm×v=6.625×10−34 m2 kg s−11.67×10−27kg×3×106  m s−1=6.625×10−34 m2 kg s−11.67×10−27kg×3×106 m s−1=1.32×10−13m=132fm\begin{align*} \lambda &= \frac{h}{p} \\ &= \frac{h}{m\times v} \\ &= \frac{6.625 \times 10^{-34}\, m^2 \, kg\, s^{-1}}{1.67 \times 10^{-27} kg \times 3 \times 10^6 \; m\, s^{-1}} = \frac{6.625 \times 10^{-34}\, m^{\cancel{2}}\, \cancel{kg}\, \cancel{s^{-1}}}{1.67 \times 10^{-27} \cancel{kg} \times 3 \times 10^6\, \cancel{m}\, \cancel{s^{-1}}} \\ \\ &= 1.32 \times 10^{-13} m = 132 fm \end{align*}λ​=ph​=m×vh​=1.67×10−27kg×3×106ms−16.625×10−34m2kgs−1​=1.67×10−27kg​×3×106m​s−16.625×10−34m2​kg​s−1​=1.32×10−13m=132fm​

children.value: A Proton with a velocity of 1% of the speed of light can probe structures more than a magnitude smaller as those accessible with X-Ray microscopes. Protons in

The Geiger-Marsden experiment, also known as the Rutherford experiment, is an experiment conducted in 1909 by Hans Geiger and Ernest Marsden under the guidance of Ernest Rutherford at the University of Manchester. The experiment was part of a series of experiments performed between 1906 and 1913 that investigated the atomic structure.

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particles (Helium nuclei consisting of two protons and two neutrons) that were guided in a beam at a thin sheet of gold foil. The source of the

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particles was radium, as it was one of the most radioacive elements known at that time. Gold was chosen for the foil as it is the most malleable metal and therefore easiest material to manufacture a thin foil with. The deflection of the

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particles was measured using a phosphorescent screen surrounding the gold foil. Each particle impacting on the screen produced a tiny flash of light that was detected “by eye”: Geiger worked in a darkened laboratory for hours, counting the scintillations using a microscope and noting the results down.

The results showed that most alpha particles passed straight through the foil however some were deflected at large angles of more than 90 degrees and even up to 180 degrees. This disproved the plum pudding model of the atom that had been proposed by Thompson.
Rutherford drew the conclusion that atoms have a small, dense, positively charged nucleus as explained in his 1911 paper

that eventually led to the widespread use of scattering in particle physics to study subatomic matter. The paper was primarily about alpha particle scattering in an era before particle scattering was a primary tool for physics.

In the following we will see how scattering experiments are used as a tool to understand the basic constituents of matter. The Geiger Marsden experiment is used to demonstrate the basic principles of these measurements.
Scattering angle in the Geiger Marsden Experiment
From the scattering measured in the experiment, we can deduce something on the relationship of the

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particles and the gold atoms (or the scattering centre).

children.value: From the above calculation using energy and momentum conservation, we deduce the following relationship:

children.value: We can analyse the equation without even knowing much about the concrete values:

Looking at the right-hand side, we find we have the multiplication of two velocities - this product is for sure positive (as there are not negative velocities). The other term on the right-hand side is

children.html: cos⁡θ\cos\thetacosθ
cos⁡θ\cos\thetacosθ

children.value: is negative for any angles larger than 90
. So the right-hand side takes on a \textit{negative} value for scattering angles larger than 90
. This of course means, that also the left-hand side needs to be negative in these cases.
Therefore, let’s take a look at the left-hand side of the equation. Again,

children.html: vt′2{v'^2_t}vt′2​
(1−mtmα)\left(1 - \frac{m_t}{m_\alpha}\right)(1−mα​mt​​)

children.value: needs to be negative, i.e. zero is larger than the left-hand side:

children.value: This shows that the target mass is larger than that of the

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particle. In fact it’s much larger by roughly a factor of 40: M(Au)

children.html: ∼\sim∼
×\times×

children.value: M(alpha). This indicates, there is a solid heavy “ball” inside the atom, not a soft distributed mass.
There is more we can learn, again using energy conservation. When the positively charged

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particle approaches the also positively charged gold nucleus it experiences a repelling force and as a consequence its kinetic energy gets converted into potential energy until it (equivalent to a ball that is tossed into the air with an initial velocity, its kinetic energy gets converted into potential energy in the gravitational field of the earth until its velocity at its highest point is zero, at which point it turns to be accelerated by the gravitational towards earth).
Using this approach we can estimate the size of an atomic nuclei as we can estimate how close the

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: Distance of closest approach in the Geiger Marsden Experiment
The potential energy of the alpha particle with charge

U=Epot=qαQAU4πϵ0rU = E_\textrm{pot} = \frac{q_\alpha Q_{\textrm{AU}}}{4 \pi \epsilon_0 r}U=Epot​=4πϵ0​rqα​QAU​​

children.value: (see also PHY11006 lecture notes: \textit{5.5 The Potential and Potential Energy of a System of Charges})

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particles and the gold nuclei repell each other as they are both positively charged. In order to estimate how close they can get, we can compare the kinetic energy of the

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particles to the potential energy caused by the charges. The kinetic energy is “used up” in order to overcome the repelling force of the electric field of the nuclei. Thus, the Kinetic energy (at t=0, i.e. when the particle approach from infinity) and potential energy are equal at the “distance of closest approach”, the point at which the

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particles are the closest to the gold nuclei, before they are deflected away from the nuclei.

children.value: Particle physics uses a specific system of units which is designed to make calculations easier - This is in contrast to the system of units that is normally used within physics, the International System of Units (SI) (
)  which is metric and what you have been dealing with so far (and in future too).

Energy is generally measured in electron-Volt (eV). An electron volt is defined as the amount of kinetic energy gained by a single electron after being accelerated from rest through an electric potential difference of 1 Volt in vacuum:

children.html: Ekin=q⋅VE_{\textrm{kin}} = q \cdot VEkin​=q⋅V
EkinE_{\textrm{kin}}Ekin​

children.value: The unit eV is used to not only measure energy but also to measure momentum and mass. In particle physics, the relationship between energy, momentum and mass is derivated using special relativity and can be expressed in this simple formula:
Relativistic relationship between energy, momentum and mass

children.value: . This is a generalisable definition: The cross section is used to quantify the effective size or the strength of an interaction with a particle. It does depend on the particle type as the size of the

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particle and the gold nuclei play a role.
As we have calculated above, the radius and thus the area of a nuclei are very small (

children.html: ∼\sim∼

children.value: femto metres). Physicists during the second world war decided to invent a new unit for the cross sectional area of nuclei and nuclear reactions, one that would also be a bit more natural in size, and tried to come up with a name. They settled on “barns” (due to the rural background of one of the physicists involved and because some of the cross-sections were as large as a barn). Today barn is used all fields of high-energy physics a unit of area which is used in cross-sections and integrated luminosity.
One barn (abbr. b) is equal to 10

children.value: How can we determine a cross-section? The easiest way to conceptualize how cross-sections and their measurements work, is to look at inclusive (or integral) cross-section. Figure a) demonstrates the principle of the measurement of an inclusive cross-section. Consider a flux of particles

children.html: J=ΔN/ΔtJ = \Delta N / \Delta tJ=ΔN/Δt

children.value: passes though the a target (in Rutherford: the foil). The particle flux decreases as:

Basically you determine the inclusive cross-section by measuring how many particle where scattered out of the beam. This is corresponding to the rate of particles being scattered depending on initial flux, target particles and cross-section.

children.value: The interpretation of the Geiger-Marsden experiment by Rutherford

children.label: The interpretation of the Geiger-Marsden experiment by Rutherford

children.value: As seen above, the mass of the nucleus is much larger than the mass of the

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particles. So when Rutherford looked into deriving a formula to describe the scattering occuring the Geiger-Marsden experiment, he assumed, there is no energy loss in the collision, that is he ignores the recoil of the target atom. It also seems, that the electrons have no impact on the scattering as the size of the nucleus, the scattering centre is so much smaller than that of the atoms. Under these conditions, the

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particle and nucleus interact through a central force, a physical problem studied already by Isaac Newton and that you have covered in
. This problem considers a central force that only acts along a line between the particles and where the force varies with the inverse square, like Coulomb force in this case.

children.value: This is the formula for Rutherford scattering!!
This formula analytically describes Rutherford scattering which is the elastic scattering of charged particles by the Coulomb interaction, sometimes also called Coulomb scattering.

Rutherford scattering is elastic scattering, but in this module we will also be looking at inelastic scattering so it’s important to understand, what the difference is. In a scattering process momentum is conserved but this is not always the case for the kinetic energy and this is where the difference lies.

In elastic collisions, the kinetic energy is conserved in addition to the momentum (e.g. snooker balls, Rutherford scattering). In these cases, you write down an equation for the energies of the particles before and after the collision and a second equation with the momenta of the particles before and after the collision {--} this later calculation can be done vectorially (i.e. under consideration of the angles of the particles). The final momenta depend on the angle of scattering and given

children.html: θ\thetaθ

children.value: we can calculate the velocities of the outgoing particles. If you look at the outcome of scattering experiments such that the Rutherford experiment, and you fix the scattering angle that you are looking at as well as the incident particle energy, you will find peaks in the spectrum of the scattered particle energies.

In inelastic collisions however, the kinetic energy is not conserved (though total energy is conserved!) and is transformed into heat or other mechanical energy (e.g. car crash) or in particle collisions into mass. Effectively, the equation for energy conservation then reads:

children.html: Ekininitial=Ekinfinal+EinternalE^\textrm{initial}_\textrm{kin} = E^\textrm{final}_\textrm{kin} + E_\textrm{internal}Ekininitial​=Ekinfinal​+Einternal​
EinternalE_\textrm{internal}Einternal​

children.value: describes the energy transformed into heat or the production of another particle. If looking at scattering of particles, you will then see a number of peaks that correspond to different values of

children.html: Ekininitial−EinternalE^\textrm{initial}_\textrm{kin} - E_\textrm{internal}Ekininitial​−Einternal​

children.value: . The internal energy is expanded for exciting the nuclei or to produce new particles.

The scattering experiments did not stop with Rutherford scattering: For very large angles (corresponding to small impact parameters where the electrons are very close to the centre of the atom and thus the nucleus) again deviations from the Rutherford formula were observed.
In these follow up experiments from the original Geiger-Marsden experiment,

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particles were scattered of various light nuclei and the experimenters used new materials as sources of

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particle which higher energies. Using higher energies for the incoming

children.html: α\alphaα

children.value: particles corresponds to shorter wavelengths and smaller structures being probed in these experiments.

children.alt: Rutherford scattering: Comparison of data with prediction

children.value: Comparison of Rutherford (or Coulomb) scattering of particles to the measured data (taken from

When comparing the number of counts as function of energy of the incoming particle or as function of the angle to the predicted count from the Rutherford Scattering formula, a deviation at high energies and large angles became apparent. Finally, the analysis of these results led to the conclusion that the alpha particle was penetrating the nucleus in these cases. Once probe come closer than radius of nulei, a new short range force, called the nuclear force, becomes important. Scattering calculated based on Coulomb potential is no longer valid. The attractive nuclear force is much stronger. **This deviation from the prediction based on a specific scattering potential is an important evidence that the potential (or force) probed at that energy **
In the following decades, with the advent of
, the particle beams used in scattering experiments became more powerful. This triggered an era of scattering experiments with nucleons and an effort to understand the nucleus.

Initially, the results were very similar to Rutherford scattering, exhibiting a signature of elastic scattering as shown in the following figure. Here, since the incoming energy and the scattering angle are fixed, the energy of the outgoing electrons is fixed as well. In this measurement, there are two peaks visible: The scattering of electrons on electrons (in the atomic shell) and of electrons with a proton or neutron from the nucleus.
Energy spectrum of 15.7 Mev electrons scattered at 30

by polystyrene (carbon). The ordinate (y-axis) represents the observed count as a function of an arbitrary energy unit on the x-axis (i.e. in this case the setting on the magnetic analyzer that selects out the energy of the scattered electrons). The
counters have a 3 percent resolution in energy (taken from

However with increasing energy and depending on the investigated materials, more complicated scattering patterns emerged as in the following figure, where apart from the elastic scattering peak, there are various other peaks visible that correspond to different excited states of Carbon.
The elastic and inelastic peaks at 187 Mev in carbon at a scattering angle of 80
Deep inelastic scattering and the discovery of proton substructure

children.label: Deep inelastic scattering and the discovery of proton substructure

children.value: In the 1960s, several sites around the world conducted scattering experiments to investigate the structure of the nucleus, that had been determined to be indeed a vaguely uniformly charged sphere. The details of the shape of the nucleus (size, charge distribution etc.) was determined in scattering experiments. The involved potential and cross-section formulae are much more involved than the one for Rutherford scattering, so these are covered in more advanced courses.

In 1966, the Stanford Linear Accelerator, a 3.2 km (2 mi) linear accelerator, was constructed  to accelerate electrons to energies of 50 GeV. It is situated on Stanford University-owned land on Sand Hill Road in Menlo Park, California, just west of the university’s main campus. Inelastic electron scattering was measured with three spectrometers in SLAC End Station A.
A beam of electrons with energy

children.html: EEE

children.value: passed through a liquid hydrogen target. Electrons that rebounded at a preselected angle

children.html: θ\thetaθ

children.value: into the acceptance of the spectrometer were analyzed for their momentum. For each given set of values

children.html: EEE
θ\thetaθ

children.value: , a series of measurements were made covering using the instrument, that already made heavy use of computer.

Experiments conducted in 1968 at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center (SLAC) and published on October 20, 1969, showed that the proton contained much smaller, point-like objects and was therefore not an elementary particle. The results no longer matching what was expected for elastic collisions on nucleons and were instead consistent with proton sub-structure.
were confirmed as constituents of the proton.

Results of electron scattering experiments discovering the substructure of the atom (left) and the proton (right). Note, that the results on the right are from the scattering of electrons on the atom and therefore deviate from the previously shown results of Rutherford scattering as negatively charged particles scatter of the atom, given a slightly different form of the potential (taken from
